awd_titl_txt: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: Semantics of Optimization for Real Time Intelligent Embedded Systems (SORTIES)
awd_abstract_narration:
Advances in technology mean that computer-controlled physical devices that currently still require human operators, such as automobiles, trains, airplanes, and medical treatment systems, could operate entirely autonomously and make rational decisions on their own. Autonomous cars and drones are a concrete and highly publicized face of this dream.  Before this dream can be realized we must address the need for safety - the guaranteed absence of undesirable behaviors emerging from autonomy. Highly publicized technology accidents such as rocket launch failures, uncontrolled exposure to radiation during treatment, aircraft automation failures and unintended automotive accelerations serve as warnings of what can happen if safety is not adequately addressed in the design of such cyber-physical systems.  One approach for safety analysis is the use of software tools that apply formal logic to prove the absence of undesired behavior in the control software of a system.  In prior work, this approach this been proven to work for simple controller software that is generated automatically by tools from abstract models like Simulink diagrams.  However, autonomous decision making requires more complex software that is able to solve optimization problems in real time. Formal verification of control software that includes such optimization algorithms remains an unmet challenge.

The project SORTIES (Semantics of Optimization for Real Time Intelligent Embedded Systems) draws upon expertise in optimization theory, control theory, and computer science to address this challenge. Beginning with the convergence properties of convex optimization algorithms, SORTIES examines how these properties can be automatically expressed as inductive invariants for the software implementation of the algorithms, and then incorporates these properties inside the source code itself as formal annotations which convey the underlying reasoning to the software engineer and to existing computer-aided verification tools.  The SORTIES goal is an open-source-semantics-carrying autocoder, which takes an optimization algorithm and its convergence properties as input, and produces annotated, verifiable code as output. The demonstration of the tool on several examples, such as a Mars lander, an aircraft avionics system, and a jet engine controller, shows that the evidence of quality produced by annotations is fully compatible with its application to truly functional products.  Project research is integrated with education through training of "tri-lingual" professionals, who are equally conversant in system operation, program analysis, and the theory of control and optimization.

por.por_cntn:
Advances in technology mean that computer-controlled physical devices that currently still require human operators, such as automobiles, trains, airplanes, and medical treatment systems, could operate entirely autonomously and make rational decisions on their own. Autonomous cars and drones are a concrete and highly publicized face of this dream. Before this dream can be realized we must address the need for safety - the guaranteed absence of undesirable behaviors emerging from autonomy. Highly publicized technology accidents such as rocket launch failures, uncontrolled exposure to radiation during treatment, aircraft automation failures and unintended automotive accelerations serve as warnings of what can happen if safety is not adequately addressed in the design of such cyber-physical systems. One approach for safety analysis is the use of software tools that apply formal logic to prove the absence of undesired behavior in the control software of a system. In prior work, this approach this been proven to work for simple controller software that is generated automatically by tools from abstract models like Simulink diagrams. However, autonomous decision making requires more complex software that is able to solve optimization problems in real-time. The development of systematically verifiable real-time optimization-based control software has been the main focus of our research project.  

The project SORTIES (Semantics of Optimization for Real-Time Intelligent Embedded Systems) has drawn upon expertise from three research groups, in optimization theory, control theory, and computer science, to address this challenge. Our research group has focused on developing convex optimization formulations of control problems and establishing the convergence properties of convex optimization algorithms to solve these problems. We also developed key demonstration examples such as control of Earth and Mars landing rockets, aerial drones, and ground rovers. These examples provided real-world test cases where we could exercise the effectiveness of the proposed algorithmic developments. For aerial drones and ground rovers, we have also demonstrated the algorithms resulting from our research in actual, physical, experiments. PI also introduced two graduate-level courses: 1) Convex optimization and its engineering applications, 2) Optimization-based robust control. Both of these courses were highly integrated with our research project. Together with laboratory test testing activities, these courses have attracted many talented undergraduate and graduate students to pursue research in optimization-based control. We also had student exchanges among PIs, which provided professional growth opportunities to graduate students working on this project. This project also led to very fruitful and ongoing research collaborations with colleagues France who are experts in formal verification. In summary, this NSF project has enabled us to produce many useful research results, provide students professional development opportunities, and develop effective collaborations between the PIs and with other researchers in the country and around the world.
